passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 22.85 AUD | Price: 21.40 AUD

In our view, PPT's relatively in line FY25 result was strong in its diversified strategy outlook (especially in CT and longer- term AM opportunities), partially moderated by WM uncertainty and cost growth. FY25 positives: 1) CT FY25 EBITDA \(+9\%\) Y/Y supported by \(5\%\) Y/Y FUA growth, and we also flag future opportunities as the Digital & Markets segment has secured an Australian Market License. 2) Boutique AM strategy supported by Pendal net inflows (excl. significant cash inflows/outflows) wherein \(100\%\) of Australian equities outperformed their benchmarks (3 yrs to Jun- 25). 3) Costs to achieve Simplification Program lowered to c.55m (vs. 70- 75m). 4) Opportunities in Alternatives (letter of intent with Partners Group) and Active ETFs (third ETF launched in Aug- 25, Active US ETF strategy with aim to launch ETFs in 2H26). FY25 negatives: 1) We remain cautious on AM net flows amidst some performance weakness across select boutiques (flagging value- style equities in particular). 2) WM market related revenue margin - 2bps Y/Y (reflecting an institutional client win), and uncertainty around the potential WM sale remains. 3) FY25 \(4\%\) Y/Y operating expense growth in upper end of 3- 4% guidance. 4) Weaker than expected DPS and FY26 DPS expected to be unfranked.

As aforementioned, we are optimistic in the outlook for PPT and opportunities across Alternatives and ETFs, but an uncertainty overhang remains from the potential WM sale. PPT is focused on reducing borrowings and strengthening their balance sheet in the near term, but substantial further debt reduction will be contingent on a potential WM sale. See inside for our scenario analysis of potential debt impact from the announced sale.

Buy rating reflects BofAe for rising AUM, flow recovery, opportunities in diversified segments and attractive valuations. PO \(22.85(+4\%\) vs. \(21.90),\) as our confidence in longer term growth offsets some near term lowered EPS expectations (see page 3 for details). We change our income rate to 8 - Same/Lower from 7 - Same/Higher to reflect DPS expectations. PPT trades at a 12.4x P/E which is - 11% vs. its 10- yr average and - \(30\%\) vs. US AM peers.

Changes to our estimates largely reflect:
Raised operating expenses to reflect guidance for 2- 3% FY26 expense growth

We remain cautious around an AM net flow turnround in the net term amidst some weakness in some boutiques' performance. However over the long term we are encouraged by new opportunities across new markets. We flag Alternatives being expected to grow at a c.6.7% CAGR over FY23- FY28E, and Active ETFs having grown at a CAGR of 39% over the past decade.
Growth in CT to be supported by diverse range of products and services, as well as growth opportunities (especially in Digital and Markets)
WM average margin reduction as a result of a change in client mix, wherein WM had a large institutional client win in FY25, as well as a change in pricing methodology for some clients.
DPS expectations lowered to reflect c.65% payout ratio expectations, wherein FY26 DPS expected to be unfranked

Costs to achieve Simplification Program revised to c. \(\) 55\(m vs. original guidance of\) \ \(70 -\) 75m. We flag \(\) 18.2\(m of costs to achieve savings incurred as FY25 significant items, hence we expect c.\) \ \(36.8m costs remain. On top of this, we also expect additional significant items (albeit reducing vs. FY25)
Exhibit 1:PPT-Estimate changes Summary of our estimate changes for PPT
BofA Global Research estimates
We estimate that the sale of the Wealth Management business would provide balance sheet support by paying down c. \(60\%\) of FY25 gross debt. Our analysis is based on the following key assumptions:

An assumed P/E of 15.0x, as based on wealth management peers Estimated transaction and separation costs of c. \(8\%\) in line with PPT's previously proposed scheme. Estimated \(30\%\) tax to be paid on the net gain on sale (after transaction costs), wherein we have assumed a c.3.3x P/B (as based on wealth management peers) to derive a book value, and subsequently a gain on sale from which this tax is paid

Exhibit 2: Based on our assumptions, we estimate a potential WM sale would provide support in paying down c. \(60\%\) of FY25 gross debt Calculating an implied balance sheet impact from the sale of the Wealth Management business

We expect Asset Management to contribute to c.56% of EBIT in FY26E, Corporate Trust to contribute to c.29% of EBIT and Wealth Management to contribute to c.18% of EBIT The removal of the Wealth Management business would see the FY26E revenue and expenses reduce by c.18%. Note that our estimates do not factor in any sale currently.

In our view, the Corporate Trust business provides a steady earnings stream for the Group having continually grown EBIT over the past decade. We were also especially pleased with the solid growth the Corporate Trust delivered this result. We highlight continuing FUA growth, various achievements (including Australian Trustee of the Year for the \(9^{\text{th}}\) consecutive year and Best Investment Platform/App award for Fixed Income Intelligence), and new opportunities in the Digital & Markets segment in particular.

We like that Corporate Trust revenues provide diversification away from markets and instead are driven out of (1) Debt Market Services, (2) Managed Fund Services, and (3) Digital and Markets vs. the Wealth Management business wherein market related revenues make up c.65% of total revenues.
We further highlight efficiency within the Corporate Trust business whose CTI ratio of c.55% remains lower than Asset Management (78%) and Wealth Management (78%).
Exhibit 4: Asset management continues to be the key contributor to revenues, BofA e for AM to contribute c.65% of FY26E revenues Division Revenue contribution by segment

Key financial summary for PPT
BofA Global Research estimates, Company reports

Our PPT price objective of A\\$22.85 is based on a standardised DCF valuation. We adjust the group's FCFE to include the value of franking credits (effectively adjusting the corporate tax rate for valuation purposes). We assume a cost of equity of \(11.65\%\) , based on a beta of 1.3x and our key fundamental assumptions which include, but are not limited to, a \(4.5\%\) long- run risk- free rate, and an equity risk premium of \(5.5\%\) . Our valuation discounts cash flows for five periods, before reverting to an assumed terminal growth rate of \(2.5\%\) .
- Value-accretive acquisitions- Short-term dividend policy remains at the top of the target range- Potential corporate appeal

- Impact of competition on flows and margins compression- Structural challenges across asset management, including availability of passive investing- Underperformance impacts sentiment and flows- Uncertainty around WM sale

iQmethod is the set of BofA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iQmethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. iQatobase is our real-time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BofA Global Research.
iQmethod, iQmethod are service marks of Bank of America Corporation. iQatobase is a registered service mark of Bank of America Corporation.
